DOC.HEAD: EC Angry Over U.S. Action in Hormone Ban
DOC.TEXT: The European Community, angered by U.S. efforts to circumvent a ban on hormone-treated beef, has asked the United States to slash retaliatory duties imposed in the trade dispute, an official said. The official said Monday that the 12-nation trading bloc wants the tariffs reduced because of legislation requiring U.S. commissaries in Europe to buy their beef from American _ not European _ producers. Commissaries are stores for U.S. military and other personnel. The official, who demanded anonymity, said the purchases plus transportation costs were expected to amount to about $55 million, which he described as an ``extra penalty'' applied by the Americans in the dispute. The United States slapped duties of about $100 million on a variety of European products to retaliate for the ban on imports of meat from cattle treated with growth hormones. Some of the duties have been eased slightly since the prohibition went into effect last Jan. 1. Frans Andriessen, the EC's top trading official, and Ray MacSharry, its agriculture chief, requested the tariffs be lifted in a Dec. 1 letter to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. No response has yet been received. Foreign ministers of the 12 community nations discussed the dispute at a meeting Monday and asked to be kept informed of the American reaction, the official said. The banned meat affects only a tiny part of the $166 billion in 1988 trade between the trading partners. The community official also said the trading bloc was considering accepting the conclusions but not critical findings of an international trade panel that ruled in favor of the United States in a dispute over soybean subsidies. The official said the community would be willing to do so provided that the United States refrained from imposing unilateral trade measures violating international trade rules. Last week, a panel of the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, found that community subsidies to processors and producers of soybeans hurt trade. Details of the soybean decision have not been released. U.S. soybean producers complained in December 1987 that community subsidies had cut into American exports to Europe. The American Soybean Association argued that the payments encouraged farmers to grow oilseeds, which then reduced the demand for American imports. The community argued the erosion of the European market was largely due to increases in cheaper imports from Brazil and Argentina.
